Package be.geertvanderpijpen.thinkinginjava.exercises.chapter02

  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    AliasingShowcase
    Part of Thinking in Java, 4th edition
    Showcases aliasing by a class with a float member
    2 seperate instances of the class are created with different values for the class member
    After that, the second instance is assigned to the first instance of the class
    The member field of the first instance is modified
    The two instances member fields are printed showing they have the same value and proving aliasing
    AlternatingBits
    Part of Thinking in Java, 4th edition
    Shows bitwise operators on values with alternating bits
    Both values have alternating 1 and 0 bits, with One value with 1 as least-significant bit One value with 0 as least-significant bit The binary operators are AND, OR, XOR and NOT
    BinaryShift
    Part of Thinking in Java, 4th edition
    Using integer variables, 31 shifts are done and at each time showing the results in binary form
    2 shifts are done 31 unsigned right shifts of 1 bit on a number that has a 1 in the most significant bit (in this case Integer.MIN_VALUE) 31 unsigned right shifts of 1 bit on the number -1
    CoinFlipping
    Part of Thinking in Java, 4th edition
    Simulates coin flipping by using the Random class.
    Dog
    Part of Thinking in Java, 4th edition
    Very basic class to represent dogs based on their name and the noise they make
    DogPlayer
    Part of Thinking in Java, 4th edition
    Creates 2 Dog objects with different names and barking sounds and prints both their name (Dog.name) and barking sound (Dog.says)
    A third Dog object is created and assigned to the first Dog instance then and references are compared using operators and the equals method
    ExponentialExtremes
    Part of Thinking in Java, 4th edition
    Prints the maximum and mimimum values of double and float data types in exponential notation
    FloatContainer
    Part of Thinking in Java, 4th edition
    Class containing one float member to demonstrate aliasing
    LongLiterals
    Part of Thinking in Java, 4th edition
    Shows that hexadecimal and octal type indicators also work with long variables
    2 long values are declared and given a value with hexadecimal value using the 0x type indicator Octal value using the leading zero type indicator
    PrintShowcase
    Part of Thinking in Java, 4th edition
    Showcase class for the Print.print(Object) method
    Prints a String with Print.print(Object) and then with System.out.println(Object)
    VelocityCalculator
    Part of Thinking in Java, 4th edition
    Calculates velocity based on a constant distance and a constanttime
    Distance and time are constant (static) class member fields
    So no other values are possible without recompilation
